is an eigenvector associated to $\lambda = -6$ (to get all eigenvectors,

hints_html: Compute the matrices \(\displaystyle A - \lambda I\) and then check eigenvectors by inspecting the nullspace of this new matrix, for each value of \(\lambda\). It will simplify matter when you use vectors with the middle entry equal to 0.
hints_latex:
Compute the matrices $\displaystyle A - \lambda I$ and then check
eigenvectors by inspecting the nullspace of this new matrix, for each
value of $\lambda$. It will simplify matter when you use vectors with
the middle entry equal to 0.
hints_raw: Compute the matrices <math>\displaystyle A - \lambda I </math> and then check eigenvectors by inspecting the nullspace of this new matrix, for each value of <math>\lambda</math>. It will simplify matter when you use vectors with the middle entry equal to 0.
question: B 04 (c)
sols_html:
We compute the matrices \(\displaystyle A-\lambda I\) and check its nullspace

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} -7 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 3 & 0 \\ -2 & 0 &-4 \end{bmatrix} - \begin{bmatrix} -5 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -5 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -5 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} -2 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 8 & 0 \\ -2 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

and from this we can see that

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

is an eigenvector associated to \(\lambda = -5\) (to get all eigenvectors, multiply this vector by any non-zero number). Repeating this with \(\displaystyle \lambda = -6\)

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} -7 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 3 & 0 \\ -2 & 0 &-4 \end{bmatrix} - \begin{bmatrix} -6 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & -6 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -6 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} -1 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 9 & 0 \\ -2 & 0 & 2 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

and from this we can see that

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 0 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

is an eigenvector associated to \(\lambda = -6\) (to get all eigenvectors, multiply this vector by any non-zero number).
sols_raw:
We compute the matrices <math> \displaystyle A-\lambda I </math> and check its nullspace

:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
-7 & 0 & 1 \\
0 & 3 & 0 \\
-2 & 0 &-4
\end{bmatrix}
- 
\begin{bmatrix}
-5 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & -5 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & -5
\end{bmatrix} = 
\begin{bmatrix}
-2 & 0 & 1 \\
0 & 8 & 0 \\
-2 & 0 & 1
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

and from this we can see that 

:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
1 \\
0 \\
2
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

is an eigenvector associated to <math>\lambda = -5 </math> (to get all eigenvectors, multiply this vector by any non-zero number). Repeating this with <math> \displaystyle \lambda = -6 </math> 

:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
-7 & 0 & 1 \\
0 & 3 & 0 \\
-2 & 0 &-4
\end{bmatrix}
- 
\begin{bmatrix}
-6 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & -6 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & -6
\end{bmatrix} = 
\begin{bmatrix}
-1 & 0 & 1 \\
0 & 9 & 0 \\
-2 & 0 & 2
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

and from this we can see that 

:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
1 \\
0 \\
1
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

is an eigenvector associated to <math>\lambda = -6 </math> (to get all eigenvectors, multiply this vector by any non-zero number).
statement_html:
Let A be the \(3 \times 3\) matrix given by

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} -7 & 0 & 1 \\ 0 & 3 & 0 \\ -2 & 0 &-4 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

It is known that \(\lambda_{1} = 3\) is an eigenvalue of A.

Find the other eigenvectors associated with \(\lambda_{2}\) and \(\lambda_{3}\)
statement_raw:
Let ''A'' be the <math> 3 \times 3 </math> matrix given by

:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
-7 & 0 & 1 \\
0 & 3 & 0 \\
-2 & 0 &-4
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

It is known that <math> \lambda_{1} = 3</math> is an eigenvalue of ''A''.

Find the other eigenvectors associated with <math> \lambda_{2} </math> and <math> \lambda_{3} </math>
